lines.content: # Cathy ‚Äì The Taskmaster You Didn‚Äôt Ask For üëπ
> *‚ÄúIf you can‚Äôt manage your life, at least let me laugh at your attempts.‚Äù* ‚Äì Cathy
Meet **Cathy**, your ~~friendly~~ brutally honest task assistant. She‚Äôs:
- **FAST SUPER FAST** (because she doesn‚Äôt waste time on your feelings)
All you need to do is:
2. Run it with `java -jar cathy.jar`. ‚Üê yes, that‚Äôs inline code, try not to cry.
4. Watch Cathy roast you while you ‚Äútry‚Äù to be productive.
## Features (aka things Cathy will judge you for)
- [x] Marking tasks as done (don‚Äôt expect a gold star)
- [ ] Smart reminders (coming‚Ä¶ if she feels like it)

* The main class for the Cathy task assistant application.
* This class provides a command-line interface for managing tasks of three types:

*
  • {@link Deadline} ‚Äì tasks with a due date/time.

*
  • {@link Event} ‚Äì tasks with a start and end time.

*
  • unmark <number> ‚Äì mark a task as not done
* ‚Äì display all {@link Deadline} and {@link Event} tasks happening on a given date
* This class also handles invalid input with custom messages via {@link InvalidTaskTypeException}.
* Constructs a new {@code Cathy} instance with a given file path for persistent storage.
* @param filePath path to the storage file

*
  • Handles errors gracefully and displays helpful messages
* Parses raw user input into {@link Command} objects for execution.

*
  • Splitting the input string into a command word and arguments

*
  • Throwing {@link CathyException} for invalid or unrecognized input
* Parses a raw user input string and returns the corresponding {@link Command}.
* @param input the raw input string typed by the user
* @return a {@link Command} representing the user's intent
* @throws CathyException if the input is null, empty, malformed, or unrecognized
public static Command parse(String input) throws CathyException {

throw new CathyException("My brain can't read your mind. Type something.");

+ "     Try again like you actually read the instructions: "

throw new CathyException("Pro tip: 'find' only works if you give me something to find.");
+ "     Try again, or type \"help\" to see what I actually understand.");

* Handles all user-facing input and output (I/O).

*
  • Printing messages, banners, errors, and task lists in a consistent style

*
  • Reading raw user input from standard input

*

This class acts as the primary interaction layer between the user
private final Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);
* Displays the welcome banner, ASCII logo, and a quick-start guide
print("I'm Cathy, your gloriously underappreciated task assistant.\n");
print("Here's what I *might* help you with (if you're lucky):\n");
print("- There are 3 types of tasks, and yes, you need to follow the format:");
print("    1. ToDos: simple tasks with no date/time. "
+ "Example command: todo visit new theme park");
print("    2. Deadlines: tasks that must be done before a date/time. "
print("    3. Events: tasks with a start and end time. "
print("       (Notice the /from and /to ‚Äì don't forget them!)");
print("- Type 'on <yyyy-MM-dd>' to see deadlines/events happening on that date.");
print("- Type 'list' to see your glorious pile of tasks.");
print("- Type 'mark <number>' to mark a task as done. Try not to mess it up.");
print("- Type 'unmark <number>' to undo a completed task.");
print("- Type 'find <keyword>' to search for tasks by description.");
print("- Type 'help' to see this list of commands. Even I can't help the clueless otherwise.");
print("- Type 'bye' to leave me in peace.");
* Prints a divider line to separate command outputs.
* Displays the concise help block that lists available commands
print("Ugh... you again? Fine, I'll repeat it. Pay attention this time.");
print("I'm Cathy, your gloriously underappreciated task assistant.\n");
print("Here's what I *might* help you with (if your brain can handle it):\n");
print("- There are 3 types of tasks, so don't mess up the format:");
print("    1. ToDos: simple tasks with no date/time. "
print("    2. Deadlines: must be done before a date/time. "
print("    3. Events: start and end times required. "
print("       (Yes, /from and /to are mandatory. Try not to forget.)");
print("- Type 'on <yyyy-MM-dd>' to see deadlines/events happening on that date.");
print("- Type 'list' to see your glorious pile of tasks (again).");
print("- Type 'mark <number>' to mark a task as done. Don't screw it up.");
print("- Type 'unmark <number>' to undo a completed task. Not that you'll remember.");
print("- Type 'find <keyword>' to search for tasks by description.");
print("- Type 'help' to see this list again... seriously, pay attention.");
print("- Type 'bye' to finally leave me alone.");
print("And yes, I'll never repeat this again... so maybe try reading this carefully.");

* Command that adds a {@link ToDo} task to the task list.

* Represents a user command in the Cathy task assistant application.
* extend this abstract class and implement the {@link #execute(TaskList, Ui, Storage)} method.

*

The {@code Parser} is responsible for constructing the correct {@code Command} subclass
* from raw user input. Then, the main loop calls {@link #execute(TaskList, Ui, Storage)} to
* Executes the command against the provided {@link TaskList}, using {@link Ui}
* to display results and {@link Storage} to persist changes.
* @param tasks   the task list to operate on
* @param ui      the user interface for showing feedback
* @param storage the storage handler for saving/loading tasks
* @throws CathyException if execution fails due to invalid input or storage issues
public abstract void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws CathyException;
* Indicates whether this command should terminate the application.

*

By default, returns {@code false}. Commands that exit the program (such as
* {@code ExitCommand}) override this to return {@code true}.
* @return {@code true} if the application should exit after executing this command;
* Command that deletes a {@link Task} from the task list by its 1-based index.
* @param index the 1-based index of the task to delete.
* Removes the task at the specified index from the {@link TaskList},
* saves the updated list via {@link Storage}, and shows a confirmation via {@link Ui}.
* @param ui      the {@link Ui} used to display feedback
* @param storage the {@link Storage} used to save the updated list
* @throws CathyException if the index is out of range (‚â§ 0 or greater than the current list size)
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws CathyException {
throw new CathyException("Nice try, but that task doesn't even exist.");
* Command that exits the Cathy application.
* Shows a farewell message via {@link Ui}. No changes are made to {@link TaskList}
* and nothing is persisted to {@link Storage}.
* @param ui      the user interface for displaying the goodbye message
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {

throw new IllegalArgumentException("Keyword must not be empty.");

This command does not modify the {@link TaskList} and does not persist anything to {@link Storage}.

* Command that lists all tasks in the current {@link TaskList}.

This command does not modify the task list and does not persist anything to {@link Storage}.

* and shows a confirmation via {@link Ui}.

public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws CathyException {
throw new CathyException("Trying to mark task " + index + " as done? Cute.\n"

public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws CathyException {

throw new CathyException("That date makes no sense. Use yyyy-MM-dd. Try again.");

* Base exception for all Cathy-related errors.

*

Use this checked exception for predictable, recoverable conditions such as invalid user input,
* parse failures, and storage I/O issues. The main loop should catch {@code CathyException}
* and display a friendly message via {@link Ui}.
* Creates a {@code CathyException} with no detail message.
* Creates a {@code CathyException} with the specified detail message.
* @param message human-readable error message to show to the user
* Exception thrown when a provided date/time string cannot be parsed
* into a valid {@link java.time.LocalDate} or {@link java.time.LocalDateTime}.

*

This is typically raised when the user provides an input string
* that does not match any supported date/time formats.

*

By default, the exception message provides guidance on the expected formats.
* Constructs a new {@code InvalidDateTimeException} with a default message
+ "     Use yyyy-MM-dd or yyyy-MM-dd HHmm. It's not that hard.");
* Constructs a new {@code InvalidDateTimeException} with a custom message.
* @param message the custom error message to be shown
* Exception thrown when a task of a specific {@link TaskType}
* is provided with an invalid or incomplete description.
* This exception customizes its error message depending on
* the type of task (TODO, DEADLINE, or EVENT) that triggered it.
* Constructs a new {@code InvalidTaskTypeException} with the
* @param type the type of task that caused the exception
* Returns a customized error message depending on the {@link TaskType}.

*
  • {@link TaskType#TODO}: complains about a missing description

*
  • {@link TaskType#DEADLINE}: complains about a malformed deadline format

*
  • {@link TaskType#EVENT}: complains about missing /from or /to details
return "Excuse you‚Äîtrying to add a todo with no description?\n"
+ "     Use: todo <desc> and try not to waste my time.";
return "Wow. That's not even close to a proper deadline format.\n"
+ "     Use: deadline <desc> /by <date> and try not to waste my time.";
+ "     Try: event <desc> /from <start> /to <end> ‚Äî give me *something* to work with.";
+ "     Try again, or type \"help\" to see what I actually understand.";
* Storage class handles saving and loading tasks to and from a file.
* Supports loading tasks at startup and saving tasks whenever the list changes.
* Constructs a Storage object with the given file path.
* Creates the parent folder if it does not exist.
* @param filePath the path to the file where tasks will be saved
* Each task is reconstructed according to its type (ToDo, Deadline, Event) and done status.
* @return an ArrayList of Task objects loaded from the file
return tasks; // file doesn't exist yet
* Saves the given list of tasks to the file.
* Each task is written in a simple format indicating type, done status, description, and dates/times.
* @param tasks an ArrayList of Task objects to save
* Represents a {@link Task} with a specific deadline.

  • a {@code by} field that stores the due date/time as a {@link LocalDateTime}.

*

The input string for {@code by} can be parsed in multiple formats:
* If the string cannot be parsed, an {@link InvalidDateTimeException} is thrown.

* @param description the description of the task
* @param by          the due date or time string. Accepts ISO-8601 or supported custom formats.
* @throws InvalidDateTimeException if the {@code by} string cannot be parsed
// Try patterns in order: datetime first, then date-only
* Returns the due date/time of this {@code Deadline}.
* @return the due date/time as a {@link LocalDateTime}
* Returns a string representation of this {@code Deadline}.
* The output includes the task type marker {@code [D]}, the description,
DateTimeFormatter outputFormat = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy, h:mma");
* Represents a {@link Task} that occurs within a specific time range.

*

Input strings for {@code from} and {@code to} can be parsed in multiple formats:

*
  • {@code yyyy-MM-dd} (date-only, defaults to start of day)

*

If parsing fails, an {@link InvalidDateTimeException} is thrown.
* If {@code from} is after {@code to}, another {@link InvalidDateTimeException} is thrown.
* Constructs a new {@code Event} with the given description, start time, and end time.
* @param description the description of the event
* @throws InvalidDateTimeException if parsing fails or {@code from} is after {@code to}
public Event(String description, String from, String to) {
// Try patterns in order: datetime first, then date-only
"Wow. You think time flows backwards? Cute.\n"
+ "     The /from date has to come *before* the /to date.\n"
+ "     Try again when you figure out how calendars work."
* Returns the start time of this event.
* @return the start time as a {@link LocalDateTime}
* Returns the end time of this event.
* @return the end time as a {@link LocalDateTime}
* Returns a string representation of this {@code Event}.
* The output includes the task type marker {@code [E]}, the description,
* and the formatted start and end date/times.
DateTimeFormatter outputFormat = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy, h:mma");
* Represents a general task with a description and a completion status.

  • {@code "X"} if the task is marked as done.

  • {@code " "} (a blank space) if the task is not done.

return (isDone ? "X" : " "); // mark done task with X

* Represents the different types of tasks supported by the system.
* Each {@code TaskType} corresponds to a specific task format:

*
  • {@link #TODO} ‚Äì A simple task with only a description.

*
  • {@link #DEADLINE} ‚Äì A task that must be completed by a specific date or time.

*
  • {@link #EVENT} ‚Äì A task that occurs within a specific time range.
* Represents a simple {@link Task} with only a description.

*
  • does not have deadlines or time ranges (unlike {@link Deadline} and {@link Event}).

* Returns a string representation of this {@code ToDo}.

ToDo t1 = new ToDo("read a book");
* Integration tests for the Parser class.
* Ensures that valid command strings are parsed and executed correctly,
* and that invalid or malformed commands throw the expected exceptions.
* Unit tests for the AddDeadlineCommand class.
* Verifies that executing the command adds a Deadline task
* with the correct description and date/time to the TaskList.
* Unit tests for the AddEventCommand class.
* Verifies that executing the command adds an Event task
* with the correct description and date/time to the TaskList.
* Unit tests for the AddToDoCommand class.
* Verifies that executing the command adds a ToDo task.
* Unit tests for the {@link DeleteCommand} class.

*
  • Executing a valid delete command removes the correct task from the TaskList.

*
  • Executing with an out-of-range index throws a {@link CathyException}.
* Unit tests for the {@link FindCommand} class.
* Verifies case-insensitive substring matching and that execution does not mutate the list.
* Unit tests for the {@link ListCommand} class.
* Verifies that executing the list command does not alter the
* contents of the {@link TaskList}, ensuring tasks remain intact
* Unit tests for the {@link MarkCommand} and {@link UnmarkCommand} classes.

*
  • Marking a task updates its status icon to "X".

*
  • Unmarking a task resets its status icon to a blank space.

*
  • Executing mark on an out-of-range index throws a {@link CathyException}.
assertEquals(" ", list.get(0).getStatusIcon()); // blank means not done
